div.p: Thank You Derrick very much and thank
you Nina and to all of you who put on
chai hack night because it's an
incredibly important part of the tech
community here in Chicago for those of
you who don't know probably 15 years ago
you could have fit the number of you who
would show up at a hack not into a
closet here at Braintree and in fact
Braintree didn't exist and and and much
of the Chicago tech community whereas
really in an asset stage so that's only
just to give you a history of where you
sit at this moment in other words where
we sit as a tech community at this
moment is historic it really has never
happened in any other city that it's
grown quite this fast and this well and
I hope you all feel that energy across
the city its energy that I want to take
across the state of Illinois we have so
much to do in the state to solve the
many problems that we face going forward
and it's going to take you frankly and
innovation and energy to solve those
problems this these are not easy
problems you all have read in the
newspaper the political challenges but
beyond the political challenges there
are financial challenges and there are
challenges about truly transforming the
way we operate our government and making
sure that we're serving people as best
we can across the state of Illinois
so let me step back and just introduce
myself for a minute
and say to you I've been married for 24
years to an obviously incredibly
tolerant woman and I've got two kids a
fourteen-year-old daughter
those of you who either have a
fourteen-year-old daughter have had a
fourteen-year-old daughter or have been
a fourteen-year-old daughter maybe you
could send me a manual I'm learning as I
go and she is a state ranked
cross-country runner really proud of
that fact she obviously gets her
athletic ability for me
and Ana Sun it was 12 years old who's
kind of a budding computer scientist and
and football fanatic and a math whiz and
contrary to maybe what some people may
know or think of me I grew up in a small
business household my parents bought a
motel and built a motel business
starting from one motel and you know
creating an environment for it that
people wanted to come to and then
another motel they acquired and built a
chain and that was the environment I
grew up in as a kid for those of you who
have parents who were in a small
business you know you were all in I no
doubt right I mean your parents talked
about it as my parents did at breakfast
at dinner you know you were working
there before it was legal to work there
and and that's how it was for me but but
the very first job that I ever had was
actually working at the motel at age 14
I was lucky enough to you know my
parents allowed me to do that and
frankly they decided they wanted to give
me like what they thought was the
hardest job at the motel and that job
they thought the hardest job was pick up
the dirty sheets from the motel
buildings and take them to the
industrial laundry facility that they'd
created on the campus of the motel load
him into the washing machine and then
move them over to the dryer that was
pretty much my first summer job I was
actually a good job though hard job but
the most memorable thing about that
first job 14 years old maybe some of you
remember going off to work
the very first day you're nervous I was
nervous and you know I had my bus money
to get to the motel and I had you know I
was just worried that I wasn't going to
live up to what my obligations you know
I had never had a boss a real boss other
than my parents before so there I was
nervous trying to head off to work and
my mother stopped me and she put her
hands on my shoulders and she said to me
now remember you have to work twice as
hard as the guy next to you
because you didn't earn this job and he
did and there are a lot of people in the
world who get said that to them by their
parents or by somebody else because they
have to work twice as hard to keep the
job or to get the job in the first place
I knew you know my mother was telling me
something different it was you're pretty
lucky you have good parents and you have
the ability to pay for college when you
go and to pursue the things you want to
pursue in your life and so you know you
better know that and so I wake up every
day thinking about I've got to work hard
to earn everything that I've been given
and so I try to do that I didn't follow
my parents into their business and
instead the lesson I took maybe like all
of you and you know what your parents
say means a lot less than what your
parents actually do and so watching them
what looked like a lot of fun to me was
just creating a business and so that's
what I went did and today you know we do
a lot of different things in our
business but one of the things we do is
we're investors in the technology world
another thing that we do is we make them
looking around to see if we make
anything that's sitting right we make
coffee sleeves so when you go to
Starbucks or other places and put a
coffee sleeve on yay and yes thank you

p.span: we actually made that coffee sleeve

div.p: right there um thank you and I did not
pay him to come here and show that off

p.span: next time you go to Starbucks

div.p: or other places and you order a coffee
and get a coffee as we've asked for -
because tell me have extra sensitive
fingers and by the way they work really
great on cold drinks - we're trying this
out you know maybe you'll fall for it
anyway they're they're environmentally

p.span: friendly fiber based products that we

div.p: make so like sandwich boxes when you go
takeout sandwich place that sort of
thing but but it's been the you know the
work that I've done in the technology
world that's where I started in business
really was in technology that that that
I've been proudest of across the you
know the city in terms of you know my
business and I was fortunate enough to
be able to pursue things like building
and you know when there was no place
really for people to build a business to
work together unless you happen to be a
student on campus at Northwestern or at
University of Chicago or at UIC if you
were just an entrepreneur who had a
really good idea and knew your market
and we're able to develop a product you
were doing that in a Starbucks or in
your own apartment and you know nobody's
maybe the engineering talent that you
might need to add to your team or
another entrepreneur to just help out
and so that was really the idea behind
1871 was that collaboration produces
success and so that's how it came about
few other things that I've been involved
in but like a lot of things that are big
and important that get created they
don't get created by one person you know
you provide some leadership and you
provide vision and you grab people and
bring them into the room maybe nonprofit
leaders and business leaders and
community leaders and everyday
Illinoisans who care deeply about the
issue that you're trying to solve and
and then you work it out you figure out
what the plan ought to be and then you
all pull on the or together once you've
got that plan and that's how we created
1871 so I've been proud to be sort of
named the founder of it but there were
an awful lot of people that I could
point to across the city of Chicago that
participated in it way before it ever
opened its doors and we didn't know if
it would be successful and people said
by the way Oh Chicago there's no chance
you're going to have that many startups
that you're going to be able to you know
fill up a place like 1871 well you you
all have proved them wrong and all the
people at 1871 and frankly the amazing
growth in the entrepreneurial community
here has proven them wrong which I think
a lot of other things that you know my
parents both my parents passed away my
mother when I was 17 my father when I
was seven but you know they they imbued
some values in me that have never left
me my brother my sister and there are
values about social justice in economic
justice they're also values of my faith
and those are things that I carry with
me everyday and things that I think
about it so when I think about you know
what would they be proud of what would
be the things that I can do in my life
that they really would say you know I'm
proud and good job they're the things
that have truly impacted tens of
thousands of people's lives across the
state of Illinois
there are 230,000 kids across Illinois
today who get school breakfast in
low-income school districts because of
the work that I did with the Greater
Chicago Food Depository and Share Our
program called no Kid Hungry at the
federal level and and expanded across
the state of Illinois into those school
districts these are kids by the way that
otherwise wouldn't eat breakfast and
maybe aren't eating dinner they get a
school lunch but we help them get a
school breakfast and you know that if
you have to go through half of your
school day hungry you're probably not
going to learn very well so it's a great
program and we were able to expand it
across the state of Illinois there are
more than 50,000 kids who go to the
Illinois Holocaust Museum every year to
learn to fight bigotry and hatred and
intolerance kids here in Illinois and we
I led the effort to build the Illinois
Holocaust Museum with the survivors with
the business community with elected the
leaders but we built that and there are
thousands of teachers that go to the
Illinois Holocaust Museum every year to
learn and take those lessons back to
their classrooms all across the state of
Illinois so that we can expand you know
the impact of learning to fight bigotry
and hatred intolerance and then 60,000
adults every year or more that visit
that museum for more than 20 years I've
led an effort to expand early childhood
education and quality preschool quality
childcare across the United States a
quarter of kids who show up at
kindergarten in the United States and
here in Illinois are not ready to learn
when they show up at kindergarten and
many of them never catch up and most of
those kids are low income kids from
black and brown communities and no one
has really stood
up for them and early childhood
important in brain development and
helping parents be better parents so in
that period of zero to five before you
show up at kindergarten eighty five
percent of brain development takes place
and yet you know as a society we haven't
really invested in those kids and
helping them succeed in those earliest
years so that's something that I've
worked on for 20 years more than 20
years and here in Illinois thousands of
kids are in quality preschool and
quality childcare because of the work
that I've done again I named all these
things in my background you're probably
wondering like gee that's great your bio
you know those are all things you did in
the past what are you going to do for me
as governor but I tell you all those
things because it's really important I
think to understand I could line up all
the candidates who are thinking about
running for governor or running for
governor today on the Democratic side
and fundamentally we agree on many
issues I'm for a progressive income tax
I think that I ought to pay a higher
rate of tax than someone who makes forty
thousand or thirty thousand dollars a
year we need a progressive income tax
and so we need to raise the minimum wage
in the state to $15 and that's not even
a you know used to be called a living
wage it's really not but we should raise
it it's $8.25 today in Illinois we
should raise it to $15 we should yeah
thank you we should legalize marijuana
in the state and and and not for yes
I saw who clap first yeah uh-huh yeah
all of you who agree clap how about that
just don't make them feel bad so um but
but there are really good reasons that
are beyond just you know let's tax it we
need the tax revenue in fact I would say
that's the third of three reasons that
we should legalize marijuana one is
safety you know I have a 14 year old a
12 year old and to my knowledge they're
not currently smoking pot of somebody
can somebody go check that and I and and
I'm not my wife's not but but but if you
get pot you don't know where it came
from mostly and you don't know what's in
it and there are a lot of people who get
it in you know and obviously they're
getting it illegally but from people who
want to get them into other drugs and
sometimes laced them with things we
should just legalize it it's the right
thing to do and as my daughter when I
asked her 14 year old when I asked her
about you know can you get into kids in
school are they able to get it for teen
and so on she said yes and then she
pointed into our living room said dad
you know there's a whole bunch of
bottles of alcohol that are sitting
there that you have for parties and
people died from that but but nobody's
ever died from smoking marijuana so you
know from the mouth of a 14 year old so
criminal justice reform is the is the
second reason the first is safety second
is criminal justice reform that's you
know kind of a plane I don't need to go

p.span: into that but but it's pretty clear and

div.p: then the third of course is their 350 to
650 million dollars of tax revenue that
we could bring into this state and
certainly revenue that we badly need
there are a lot of issues my point was
that if you lined up all the candidates
not every candidate agrees about
marijuana but but we all agree on you
know progressive income tax and and and
raising the minimum wage and and a
series of other issues which we I hope
we'll get a chance to talk about tonight
but the question you have to ask
yourself is every politician every
person running for office stands up and
tells you what you want to hear and and
yet not everybody has the capability to
actually get those things done and so I
think the question that you should ask
about the candidates is what have they
done what were they doing in fact when
they weren't running for public office
to make people's lives better what what
impacted they have when they weren't
surveying or what you know when they
were just being themselves and in their
own careers what were they doing before
they decided to run and those are things
I mean I'm proud of the things that I've
gotten accomplished they're big things
they're things that affected have
affected maybe more than a hundred
thousand people in the state of Illinois
but tens of thousands of people
certainly and and and I believe today
that you know bringing people together
to solve problems big problems is
certainly what we need in Springfield if
anybody watched the catastrophe that was
the you know entire budget debate over
the last number of months and frankly
over the last two years I think we would
all say that this state lacks leadership
certainly this governor who you know
took off his Rolex and put it in a
drawer and put on a Timex watch and
decided to put a plaid shirt on and then
he put a Carhartt jacket on dropped his
geez and ran and got elected and then
all of a sudden he pulled out from
underneath his jacket the hidden agenda
and the hidden agenda which he held the
state hostage to for more than two years
agenda night that sounds like hyperbole
it's not in every state around us in the
Midwest they've succeeded at getting
right-to-work legislation passed and
therefore destroying unions at bringing
down wages at fighting against workplace
safety to make it cheaper for businesses
to operate in those states and and
they've won I mean they have won with
Republican governors Scott Walker and so
on if you every state around us if you
look at the map of 2016 and the election
in 2016 it's there's a blue Illinois and
red all the way around our state all the
way around and to us to me anyway that
looks like an island that we have to
protect
to the koch brothers and to you know to
those who support the koch brothers in
their network that looks like a
bull's-eye the blue spot in the middle
looks like a bull's-eye and they already
have a governor who is part of their
network fighting for this agenda and we
have to defeat him 2018 you may have
heard this in 2016 2014 and prior but in
2018 truly in illinois this is the most
important election of our lifetimes i'm
older than a lot of people in the most
important election of my lifetime I
thought 2016 was most important election
of my lifetime by the way it may have
been in retrospect but now here we are
heading toward 2018 and then will Kareem
quickly toward 2020 but in 2018 if we do
not win we will probably be a
right-to-work state we will probably
have lower wages in the state we will
probably have a destroyed safety net in
this state and even if you are not
touching the safety net today and even
if you are not friends with somebody

div.p: into the safety net in the state someone
in your community is and it's there for
you because anything can happen because
oh wait oh 9 and the Great Recession
could happen again and we saw that

were destroyed biota 8:09 and needed

again Illinois has ripped that apart
because of Bruce rauner so we need a

and have a safety net that protects
people and fundamentally what I believe
is we have to fight for our safety net
we have to fight for people who are
trying to achieve getting to the middle

things that that we've got to do in the
state means creating jobs and raising

and against Trump care which will
destroy health
during the state and the finances of our
state and we've got a maybe maybe the
most important thing for the future of
our state we've got to rebuild the

the state of Illinois 50th the state of
Illinois is 50th in state funding for

government provides 26% of k-12
education funding the rest of it is
property taxes 26% comes from the state
the average state in the United States

cuts in university funding I mean it's

we all know that we've got great private

can't sustain it and we're a great state
more best known many of the reasons that
people move to Illinois and move their

and and raise their families here many
of the reasons are we have really
well-educated and dedicated people here
and if people are going to get up and

I'm going to pin this on our governor
because he really has done this he's

that were you know that everybody here

those are the things you hear about and

so so these challenges are

their community wherever they may be

so I want to debunk that and frankly I
won't be a governor who's for one part

state because it isn't about that we
have so much to do across the state of
Illinois I mean I live here in Chicago
but I have traveled all over the state
as a candidate I've only been a

a good portion of that frankly outside
of Cook County because it is so
important for people to get hope back
and when you go to coal country I'll
just give you the example of you know
people have lost their jobs because you
know there's a diminution of the use of

unions that represent them are gone and
we do still produce coal in the state
but it's being shipped to China and it's

challenges people are not only out of
work but I need destitute and we see
that here in Cook County too not about
coal but about other things where people
are truly destitute so I just want to
debunk the whole idea I'm doing my best
to try to be a candidate and then a
governor for all of Illinois and again
that means about focusing on the primary
issues that are I think important for
the future particularly the next stories
we have to have someone who's going to
stand up for a balanced budget which you
know this governor didn't do stand up
for education make sure that we're
paying for k-12 education and the

we have a budget but actually schools

that effect and that you know the one

it really does make one major

out of the school funding formula
I mean the poorest kids in the state are
actually going to be the first ones to

change
Chicago will also get 300 million

what would you do to bring Illinois to a

first the start of that there two starts
I want to make two that one is we should
essentially here in Illinois live up to

doesn't get us to 100% clean energy it
just but it gets us you know on the path

and and I'll be a governor that will

all know in the tech world that that the

that's something that we ought to be

we do have you know argon for example we

let you last little comment I'd make is
just about Donald Trump because I didn't

everybody contract was made you took a
